text: Corydoras is a genus of catfish in the family Callicthyidae. They are called corydoras or cory catfish. They are the most well-known callichthyids. The emerald catfish is the largest Corydoras. == Species == This genus has 162 species. 161 are extant, while only one is extinct: * Corydoras acrensis Nijssen, 1972 (Acre corydoras) * Corydoras acutus Cope, 1872 (Black-top corydoras) * Corydoras adolfoi W. E. Burgess, 1982 (Adolfo's catfish) * Corydoras aeneus (T. N. H. Eigenmann & W. R. Allen, 1942 (Black-band catfish) === Extinct species === * †Corydoras revelatus Cockerell, 1936 == Habitat == Corydoras are generally found in a variety of freshwater environments, such as rivers, streams, and tributaries. They are native to slow-moving and almost still (but seldom stagnant) streams and small rivers of South America, where the water is shallow and very murky. == Description == Corydoras have a short body with a dorsal fin and forked tail. They have whiskers (more specifically, barbels) like all catfish. The "whiskers" help them detect food. == Aquarium use == Corydoras are popular and hardy aquarium fish. They are well-known for their vibrant colors and unique patterns. They are also famous for their peaceful behavior. The Corydoras is a wonderful fish to many home aquariums. == What it eats == === In the wild === Corydoras in the wild feed on small aquatic invertebrates, like worms, crustaceans, and insect larvae. === Aquarium === Corydoras in an aquarium will eat live food like brine shrimp and others. == Related pages == * Brook stickleback * Three-spined stickleback == References == # "Handle those catfish with care! - Practical Fishkeeping". 13 June 2016. Category:Catfish
title: Corydoras
